name: Always prefer to set Array designators "[]" on the type and not at variable
description:
"int[] array = new int[10];" and "int array[] = new int[10];" are both basically same, there is no difference in performance.

But, this syntax "int[] array = new int[10];" is recommended as best practice for readability. Otherwise, developers must look both at the type and the variable name to know whether or not a variable is an array.


This rule will report violation when an Array designator is not set on the type
output:
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided:
- The number of violation occurrences
- Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
rationale: When the array designators are used on the type it improves code readability otherwise developers must look both at the type and the variable name to know whether or not a variable is an array.
remediation: "int[] array = new int[10];" is recommended as best practice for readability.
sample:
int matrix[][];   // Violation 
int[] matrix[];   // Violation
alternativeName: Prefer using array designators, while declaration, on the type and not on the variable
